notesStmt.note: Defective at the end. Folio 112 partly mutilated.
A Latin description of the manuscript has been pasted on folio .
Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

msContents.summary: A maḥzor containing the services for the special Sabbaths, Pesaḥ and Shavu῾ot, according to the German rite.

collation.p: Quires of mostly 8 leaves each, signed with catchwords at the end.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Ashkenazi square script of the 14th century. Punctuated.

binding.p: Post-1600. Harleian thick red leather binding with gold-tooling. Spine: 'Pars T. Machazor Judaeorum Germanorum. Hebr. Cod. Sec. XIV. Mus. Brit. Bibl. Harl. 5714. Plut. XXXIII.I.' Boxed.

history.provenance: Acquisition: The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts, inscribed as usual by their librarian, Humfrey Wanley, '18 die Januarij, A.D. 1723/4' (folio ). Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta Cavendish, née Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d.1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
